chapter.title: Introduction to the Meteor Framework
chapter.para:
The chapter is an introduction to how Meteor implements its design goals. To reiterate, the Meteor framework has four main design goals which were adopted in order to meet its business goal of making it possible to profitably develop system software for small businesses:
Dynamic, modular system assembly.
Model-driven system functionality.
Unanticipated customation, or customization without hooks.
Provide the most common system functionality out-of-the-box.

section.title: Java
section.para: Meteor uses Java as the underlying runtime platform. The Java community provides a wealth of open source libraries that Meteor reuses. In the future it is highly probable that Meteor will support the development of Meteor modules in other languages that run on the Java Virtual Machine but for now all Meteor modules are developed with Java.

section.title: Dynamic, modular system assembly: OSGi Bundles
section.para: Meteor's first design goal is to make it possible to assemble a software system from modules. Instead of defining its own concept of what a module is Meteor instead has adopted the OSGi Service Framework as the standard for defining what a module is, how modules are deployed, installed, started, etc. Therefore, all Meteor functionality is package into OSGi 'bundles'. All Meteor-based systems run on top of an OSGi 'engine' that manages all bundles.

A central focus of the OSGi framework is the concept of 'services'. Meteor is designed to integrate well with existing OSGi services by making it possible to automatically 'inject' standard OSGi services into Meteor-managed resources and to automatically export Meteor-managed services as OSGi services.
The OSGi framework also defines many standard services, like a Logging service, a Remoting service, etc. Meteor takes advantage of available OSGi services whenever possible.
Meteor uses the open source Felix OSGi engine as its OSGi engine, however Meteor should work with other OSGi implementatio such as Equinox and Concierge.

section.title: Model-driven system functionality: RDF (Resource Description Format) metadata repository
Why RDF?
section.para: Meteor's second design goal is to provide a global metadata repository. A metadata repository enabled model-driven development and make it possible for a module to provide an aspect of functionality for the entire system. For instance, when the repository contains a description of all objects that will be persistently stored then a single module can provide persistent storage to a database for the entire system based on the data in the repository.

Meteor has adopted the Resource Description Format (RDF) for representing metadata. RDF is a general method for conceptual description or modeling of information. Meteor defines a Java API for accessing and manipulating RDF data. Meteor all supports the Turtle RDF serialization format.

Meteor uses RDF mainly because RDF makes it easy to do one thing that's not easy to do in other modeling methods: RDF makes it easy for one module to state facts about data in another module. For instance, suppose one module contain metadata that defines contact information for a person. Then suppose that another module wants to add a twitter id to that contact information. This is exactly the kind of thing that is easy to do with RDF but is quite difficult to do with other methods. This feature of RDF is exactly what is needed in order to make it possible for modules to customize each other.

section.title: What data is available in the repository?
Unanticipated Customization: Metadata-driven Generic functions, Decorators, Interceptors and Dependency Injection
section.para:
Some existing application development frameworks make it easier to customize software by adding what are called hooks, or extension points. Take for example an order management module that calculates sales commissions on orders and suppose that this module wants to allow other modules to be able to customize how commissions are calculated. In many other frameworks in order to make it possible for other modules to customize the calculation of sales commissions the order management module would be required to define an 'extension-point', or hook, that other modules could use to register additional calculation methods. The problems with this type of customization are:
It requires significant extra effort on the part of the developer to create the hooks used for customization and extension
It limits reuse since hooks have to be created before a module can be customized. However, developers never anticipate all the ways in which other developers may want to customize a module and even if they do they often don't make the effort to create hooks until and unless they know someone else is going to use them.
For these reasons it is better to support an extension and customization scheme that does not require hooks, a scheme that enables modules to directly 'plug into' objects from other modules.
section.section:
Generic functions
In Meteor all available functionality is defined by Java interfaces and Meteor gives all modules the ability to customize the behavior of any method of any interface defined by any other module. In Meteor all interface methods are implemented using a technique called generic functions. A generic function is a Java interface method and an associated collection of Java class methods each of which implements the interface method. At runtime when the interface method is invoked a subset of the methods are selected for execution (depending on the current runtime context) and arranged in a stack for execution. The first invoked method may choose to return a result and complete the invocation or it may choose to pass the invocation further down the stack to the next method.
Generic functions are described in detail in later sections.
</section
Guice in Meteor
Instead of inventing its own method of enabling the ability to customize behavior Meteor uses another framework called Guice to provide this functionality. Guice is well-know as a 'dependency injection' library but Guice also implements a capability know as 'interceptors', the ability to intercept and customize a method invocation on an interface. Metoer reuses Guice to provide the ability to customize method invocations and also reuses Guice's dependency injection capability. However, using Guice directly to customize behavior can be quite tedious. Another problem with using Guice directly is that it's impossible for someone to get a complete picture of how the modules in a system customize each other. Therefore Meteor introduces the ability for modules to simply create 'decorator' and 'interceptor' classes that plug-into interface implementations. Meteor then automatically creates system metadata that describes how decorator and interceptor classes should be assembled into interface implementation. Meteor also automatically configures Guice with the appropriate interceptors. Decorator and interceptor classes may then use Guice annotation for dependency injection purposes. Guice annotations may be used to inject Meteor-managed objects as well as OSGi services.
Decorator and Interceptor classes
To make Guice easier to use in a modular system Meteor introduces the ability for modules to simply create 'decorator' and 'interceptor' classes that can be plugged-into interface implementations. Meteor then automatically creates system metadata that describes how decorator and interceptor classes should be assembled into interface implementation. Meteor also automatically configures Guice with the appropriate interceptors. Decorator and interceptor classes may then use Guice annotation for dependency injection purposes. Guice annotations may be used to inject Meteor-managed objects as well as OSGi services. The details of Decorators and Interceptors are described in this section.
Because Meteor creates metadata in the system metadata repository that describes how decorators and interceptors are wired together it is possible to create a module to provide a system 'view' that provides a convenient view of the system for understanding how modules are wired together. Currently Metoer comes with a simple utility that creates a document to show what modules contribute functionaly to what interfaces.
